block.p: ATTRACTIONS
Museums and Sites

AMERICAN MUSEUM OF THE MOVING IMAGE, 34-12 36th Street, at 35th Avenue, Astoria, Queens. ''Behind the Mirror: American Film in the 1950's,'' through Sept. 3. Tomorrow, two films directed by Otto Preminger: at 1:30 p.m., ''The Man With the Golden Arm'' (1955); at 4 p.m., ''Anatomy of a Murder'' (1959). Sunday at 2 p.m., Elia Kazan's ''Face in the Crowd'' (1957); at 4:30 p.m., Frank Tashlin's ''Will Success Spoil Rock Hunter?'' (1957). Tomorrow and Sunday at 6:30 p.m., Akira Kurosawa's ''Rashomon'' (1951). All activities are free with museum admission unless otherwise indicated. Admission: $8.50; the elderly and students, $5.50; ages 5 to 18, $4.50; 4 and under, free. Information: (718) 784-0077.
ATTRACTIONS
Museums and Sites

AMERICAN MUSEUM OF THE MOVING IMAGE, 34-12 36th Street, at 35th Avenue, Astoria, Queens. ''Behind the Mirror: American Film in the 1950's,'' through Sept. 3. Tomorrow, two films directed by Otto Preminger: at 1:30 p.m., ''The Man With the Golden Arm'' (1955); at 4 p.m., ''Anatomy of a Murder'' (1959). Sunday at 2 p.m., Elia Kazan's ''Face in the Crowd'' (1957); at 4:30 p.m., Frank Tashlin's ''Will Success Spoil Rock Hunter?'' (1957). Tomorrow and Sunday at 6:30 p.m., Akira Kurosawa's ''Rashomon'' (1951). All activities are free with museum admission unless otherwise indicated. Admission: $8.50; the elderly and students, $5.50; ages 5 to 18, $4.50; 4 and under, free. Information: (718) 784-0077.

AMERICAN MUSEUM OF NATURAL HISTORY, Central Park West and 79th Street. ''Fighting Dinosaurs: New Discoveries From Mongolia,'' featuring one of the most famous fossil finds in the world; through Oct. 29. ''Mongolia Observed: Photographs Present and Past,'' featuring 40 color images by Robert Peck and black-and-white photographs by the explorer Ray Chapman Andrews from the 1920's and 30's. Imax films are ''To Be an Astronaut'' and ''Dolphins.'' In the Imax Theater tonight and tomorrow night at 9, ''Laser Aerosmith in 3-D''; at 10, ''Laser Led Zeppelin.'' Laser show tickets: $12. Museum hours: Sundays through Thursdays, 10 a.m. to 5:45 p.m.; Fridays and Saturdays, 10 a.m. to 8:45 p.m. Admission (suggested donation): $10 for adults; $7.50 for students and the elderly; $6 for children. Combination tickets are available. Information: (212) 769-5100; advance tickets: (212) 769-5200.

AMERICAN MUSEUM OF NATURAL HISTORY'S ROSE CENTER FOR EARTH AND SPACE, Central Park West at 81st Street. This 333,500-square-foot, seven-floor, 120-foot-high exhibition and research center includes the new Hayden Planetarium, the Cullman Hall of the Universe and the Gottesman Hall of Planet Earth. The Hayden Planetarium contains the Space Theater, presenting ''Passport to the Universe,'' and the Big Bang Theater, featuring narrated visual and audio effects simulating the beginning of the universe. ''Starry Nights: Fridays Under the Sphere,'' music tonight from 5:45 to 8, with Bobby Sanabria y Quinteto Ache, through next Friday. Free with admission; food and cash bar. ''Full Moon: Apollo Mission Photographs of the Lunar Landscape,'' from NASA's Apollo missions to the moon; through Sept. 23. Hours: Sundays through Thursdays, 10 a.m. to 5:45 p.m.; Fridays and Saturdays to 8:45 p.m. Space shows run throughout the day. Admission (suggested donation) to the American Museum of Natural History, which includes the Rose Center: $10; for students and the elderly, $7.50; children 12 and under, $6; under 2, free. Admission to the museum, the Rose Center and the Hayden Planetarium space show: $19; students and the elderly, $14; children 12 and under, $11.50; under 2, free. Information: (212) 769-5100. Reservations: (212) 769-5200.

HISTORIC RICHMONDTOWN, Staten Island Historical Society, 441 Clarke Avenue, Richmondtown. More than 25 buildings from the late 17th century to the 19th century, restored and furnished. This village and outdoor museum depict the history of Staten Island and the surrounding region. In ''Living History,'' through next Friday, costumed interpreters will demonstrate the skills and trades of their earlier counterparts, including the tinsmith, storekeeper and dollmaker. Admission: $5; $2.50 for the elderly and children 6 to 16; under 6, free. Tomorrow night from 8 to 11, Regimental Ball, including torch lights, music, 19th-century dance; visitors may dress in the style of the period. Free. The exhibition ''Toys!'' will run through December 2001. Guided tours are available. Hours through Sept. 1: Wednesdays through Fridays, 10 a.m. to 5 p.m.; Saturdays and Sundays, 1 to 5 p.m. Admission: $4; the elderly and children 6 to 18, and students, $2.50; 5 and under, free. Information: (718) 351-1611.

INTREPID SEA-AIR-SPACE MUSEUM, Pier 86, West 46th Street at the Hudson River, Clinton. The Intrepid is a converted World War II aircraft carrier with two full decks of displays, including four theme halls: United States Navy Hall, Pioneer Hall, Technologies Hall and Intrepid Hall. Tomorrow and Sunday on the pier at 1, 2:30 and 4 p.m., the U.S.O. Troupe of Metropolitan New York performs songs from the 1940's to today. Admission: $12; the elderly, veterans, reservists and ages 12 to 17, $9; ages 6 to 11, $6; ages 2 to 5, $2; under 2, free; wheelchair patrons, half price. Hours: Mondays through Fridays, 10 a.m. to 5 p.m; Saturdays and Sundays, 10 a.m. to 6 p.m. Information: (212) 245-0072.

MUSEUM OF CHINESE IN THE AMERICAS, 70 Mulberry Street, Chinatown. Silkscreened banners and other works by Brenda Joy Lem, through tomorrow. On permanent display is ''Where Is Home? Chinese in the Americas,'' a collection of photographs and other artifacts, and ''Family Portraits,'' photographs of Chinatown residents. Hours: Tuesdays through Saturdays, noon to 5 p.m.; closed holidays. Admission: $3; the elderly and students, $1; 12 and under and museum members, free. Information: (212) 619-4785.

MUSEUM OF JEWISH HERITAGE: A LIVING MEMORIAL TO THE HOLOCAUST, 18 First Place, at West Street and Battery Place, Battery Park City, Lower Manhattan. Artifacts, documents, photographs, videos and film clips are included in exhibitions on the Holocaust and on Jewish life before and after World War II.''My House to Your House: A Workshop of Family Traditions,'' a workshop Sunday from 11 a.m. to noon. ''Children of a Vanished World: Photographs by Roman Vishniac,'' through Oct. 20. Hours: Sundays through Wednesdays, 9 a.m. to 5 p.m.; Thursdays until 8 p.m.; Fridays and the eves of Jewish holidays, 9 a.m. to 5 p.m.; closed Saturdays. Admission: $7; students and the elderly, $5; children 5 and under, free. Tickets can be bought in advance through Ticketmaster, (212) 307-4007, or by calling the museum on the day of the visit, (212) 945-0039. Information: (212) 509-6130.
Gardens

BROOKLYN BOTANIC GARDEN, 900 Washington Avenue, Prospect Heights. Through Sept. 16, butterfly and hummingbird trails open for tours, with related crafts and other activities on weekends. The Japanese Hill and Pond Garden is open, with guided tours available. ''Photographs of Winners 1995-2000, Greenest Block in Brooklyn,'' through tomorrow. A children's art show of drawings and paintings in the Steinhardt Gallery, opening tomorrow and through Oct. 9: Tuesdays through Sundays, 10 a.m. to 5:30 p.m. Admission: $3; $1.50 for students and the elderly; free for children 15 and under; free on Tuesdays, except holidays; free from 10 a.m. to noon on Saturdays. Hours: Tuesdays through Fridays, 8 a.m. to 6 p.m.; Saturdays, Sundays and holidays, 10 a.m. to 6 p.m. The conservatory closes 30 minutes before the grounds. Information: (718) 623-7200.

QUEENS BOTANICAL GARDEN, 43-50 Main Street, Flushing. More than 39 acres devoted to woodland and bird, bee and perennial gardens. August blooms include clethra, sunflowers, myrtle, hibiscus and dahlias. Tomorrow from 10 a.m. to noon, a talk on natural lawn care. Free. Hours: daily, 8 a.m. to 6 p.m.; Saturdays and Sundays, 8 a.m. to 7 p.m.; closed Mondays. Garden admission is free. On weekends a trolley runs to Flushing Meadows-Corona Park. Information: (718) 886-3800.

STATEN ISLAND BOTANICAL GARDEN, 1000 Richmond Terrace, Livingston. The garden covers 83 acres, with neo-Classical buildings that once housed retired seamen. Hours: daily, dawn to dusk. Free admission to the grounds. The one-acre New York Chinese Scholars' Garden is open. ''China: Ancient Art and Sciences,'' featuring 13 artisans from China demonstrating their craft and 300 works of art; through Oct. 1. Hours: Tuesdays through Sundays, 10 a.m. to 5 p.m. Admission to the Chinese Scholars' Garden: $7.50; $5 for the elderly and students and children under 12; under 1, free. Information: (718) 273-8200.
Cruises

ADIRONDACK, leaving from Chelsea Piers Sports and Entertainment Complex, 23rd Street on the Hudson River. An 80-foot schooner that goes on two-hour sails daily around New York Harbor at 10:30 a.m., 1, 3:30, 6 and 9 p.m. Tickets: weekdays, $30 for all sails except the 6 and 9 p.m. sail, which is $40, and includes drinks; weekends, $35 for all sails except the 6 and 9 p.m. sail, which is $45, including drinks. Information: (800) 701-7245.

CIRCLE LINE CRUISES, leaving from Pier 83, 42nd Street at the Hudson River, Clinton. A two-hour, 24-mile cruise around southern Manhattan passing landmarks like Ellis Island and the United Nations, daily at 11 a.m., 2 p.m. and 4:30 p.m. Tickets: $20; children 12 and under, $10; the elderly, $16. A three-hour, 35-mile cruise around all of Manhattan, daily at 9:30, 10:15 and 11:45 a.m., 12:30, 1:15, 2:45 and 3:30 p.m. Tickets: $24; children 12 and under, $12; the elderly, $19. ''Harbor Lights,'' daily at 7 p.m. Tickets: $20; children 12 and under, $10; the elderly, $16. ''The Beast,'' 30-minute speedboat ride in the harbor, daily, every hour on the hour, 11 a.m. to dusk, except Wednesdays, when it is 2 p.m. to dusk. Tickets: $15; children 5 to 12, $10. Information: (212) 563-3200.

WORLD YACHT, leaving from Pier 81, 41st Street at the Hudson River, Clinton. Daily dinner cruises along the West Side of Manhattan and around New York Harbor, from 7 to 10 p.m., boarding at 6 p.m. Prices: Fridays, $75; Saturdays, $79; Sundays, $67 (does not include beverages, taxes or gratuities). Brunch cruises sail on Sundays from 12:30 to 2:30 p.m., with boarding at 11:30 a.m. Price: $39.95. Information: (212) 630-8100.

N.Y. WATERWAY, leaving from Pier 78, West 38th Street and 12th Avenue, Clinton. Daily two-hour full Manhattan cruise, at 10:30 a.m. and 1:30 p.m., through Nov. 12. Tickets: $24; $19 for the elderly; $12 for children ages 3 to 12; 2 and younger, free. Daily, a 90-minute cruise of New York Harbor; at 10 a.m., 11 a.m., noon, 1 p.m., 2, 3 and 4 p.m. Tickets: $19; the elderly, $16; ages 3 to 12, $9; 2 and younger, free. Fridays at 10:15 p.m., disco cruise. Price: $19; $9 for children. A 70-minute twilight tour leaves daily, except Tuesday, at 8:45 p.m.; additional tours on Saturdays at 7:15 and 10:15 p.m. and on Sundays at 7:15. Tickets: $19; the elderly, $16; children, $9. Information: (800) 533-3779.

PIONEER, the historic schooner, sails from the South Street Seaport Museum's Pier 16, South and Fulton Streets, Lower Manhattan, for a two-hour cruise. Sunset cruises Tuesdays through Sundays at 7 p.m.; 9:30 p.m. sails Tuesdays through Saturdays; additional sails Saturdays and Sundays at 1 and 4 p.m. Tickets: sunset cruises $25; other sails $20, $15 for students and the elderly and $12 for children 12 and under.
EVENTS

''SUNSET JAM ON THE HUDSON,'' Wagner Park, Battery Park City, Lower Manhattan. Featuring a rotating trio of percussionists: Mary Knyshok, Peter Hawes and Pamela Patrick. Tonight at 6:30. Free. Sponsored by Battery Park City Parks Conservancy. Information: (212) 267-9700.

''A FOOD ADVENTURE OF GREENWICH VILLAGE.'' Combines tastings at local restaurants and specialty food stores with a stroll. Meets Tuesdays through Sundays at 11:30 a.m. Sponsored by Foods of New York. Fee: $25 (includes food). Information and meeting place: (732) 636-4650.
RECREATION

NEW YORK CITY MARATHON TUNE-UP, Central Park. An 18-mile run, Sunday at 8 a.m. Begins and starts on the East Drive near 99th Street. Sponsored by the New York Road Runners Club. Advance registration fee, $17, $12 for club members; $10 for junior and senior club members. Race-day registration for challenge race, $22, $15 for club members; $12 for junior and senior club members. Information: (212) 860-4455.
ON THE STREET
GREENWICH AVENUE FESTIVAL, Greenwich Avenue, from Seventh to Eighth Avenues, West Village. Tomorrow, 11 a.m. to 7 p.m. Sponsored by the Horatio Street Association.
GRAMERCY PARK NEIGHBORHOOD FESTIVAL, Third Avenue, from 14th to 23rd Streets. Sunday, 11 a.m. to 6 p.m. Sponsored by the Gramercy Park Republican Club.

SAVE WASHINGTON SQUARE PARK FESTIVAL, Washington Square North, from Macdougal Street to University Place, West Village. Tomorrow, 11 a.m. to 7 p.m. Sponsored by the Save Washington Square Park Coalition.
DAYTOP'S MADISON AVENUE FESTIVAL, Madison Avenue, from 43rd to 56th Streets. Sunday, 11 a.m. to 6 p.m. Sponsored by Daytop Village.
PAKISTAN INDEPENDENCE DAY PARADE, Madison Avenue from 41st Street to 26th Street. Sunday at 1 p.m.
WALKING TOURS

''FROM WAMPUM TO WALL STREET: THE AMERICAN INDIAN HERITAGE OF MANHATTAN ISLAND,'' Lower Manhattan. Traces the interaction of American Indians with Dutch and English settlers. Meets today at 2 p.m. inside Blimpie's, 38 Park Row, between Beekman and Spruce Streets. Fee: $12. Sponsored by Dr. Phil: New York Talks and Walks. Information: (888) 377-4455.

''GRAMERCY PARK,'' an architectural tour of an area that includes the city's only private park, as well as some of its earliest apartment houses. Meets today at 11 a.m. on the southwest corner of Third Avenue and 17th Street. Sponsored by the Municipal Art Society. Fee: $15; $12 for students, the elderly and members of the Municipal Art Society. Information: (212) 935-3960.

''JAZZ NIGHTS IN HARLEM.'' A tour of the area, followed by dinner and a stop at a jazz club. Meets tonight and tomorrow night at 7:30 p.m on the northeast corner of Lenox Avenue and 125th Street. Fee: $50. Sponsored by Harlem Heritage Tours. Reservations: (212) 280-7888.

TWILIGHT BROOKLYN BRIDGE TALK AND WALK. Discusses the Roebling family, instrumental in the building of the bridge, and the importance of the structure itself. Meets tonight and tomorrow at 6 p.m. in Blimpie's Restaurant, 38 Park Row, Lower Manhattan. Fee: $12. Sponsored by Dr. Phil: New York Talks and Walks. Information: (888) 377-4455.

''THE SILK PURSE: MILLIONAIRE'S MILE,'' Manhattan. See the private clubs, cultural institutions and palatial homes of rich and famous past residents. Meets tomorrow at 1 p.m. at the statue of General Sherman at 59th Street and Fifth Avenue. Fee: $10. Sponsored by I'll Take Manhattan Tours. Information: (732) 270-5277.

''AMERICAN REVOLUTION AND BROOKLYN BRIDGE ON THE ANNIVERSARY OF THE BATTLE OF BROOKLYN HEIGHTS,'' Lower Manhattan. A tour of sites associated with people and events of the Revolution, beginning in Manhattan, followed by a walk across the Brooklyn Bridge. Tomorrow at 3:30 and 6:15 p.m. and Sunday at 3 p.m. Fee: $12. Sponsored by NYC Discovery Tours. Information: (212) 465-3331.

''BATS! A NIGHT TOUR IN PROSPECT PARK,'' Brooklyn, searches for the nocturnal creatures in the ravine. Meets tomorrow at 8 p.m. at the Tennis House, inside Prospect Park, near the Ninth Street entrance. Sponsored by the Brooklyn Center for the Urban Environment. Fee, $8; $6 for center members; $5 for students and the elderly. Information: (718) 788-8500, Extension 401.

''LITERARY GARRETS OF GREENWICH VILLAGE.'' Visits the homes or places of significance in the lives of Theodore Dreiser, Edna St. Vincent Millay, Edgar Allan Poe, Marianne Moore and others. Meets tomorrow at 2 p.m. in front of the Jefferson Market Library, Avenue of the Americas and 10th Street. Fee, $12. Sponsored by Dr. Phil: New York Talks and Walks. Information: (718) 377-4455.

''TREES, MEADOW AND LAKE'' will be covered on a tour of Prospect Park sponsored by the Friends of the Parks. Meets Sunday at 1:45 p.m. at Bartel-Pritchard Circle, at Prospect Park West and 15th Street. Contribution, $1.

''HISTORIC EAST BROADWAY,'' Lower Manhattan. Among the stops on this tour of historic synagogues and other sites are the Eldridge Street Synagogue and the Congregation Sons of Moses. Meets Sunday at 1 p.m. at the Eldridge Street Synagogue, 12 Eldridge Street. Fee, $18; $1 for students and the elderly. Sponsored by the Lower East Side Conservancy. Information: (212) 598-1200.

''MIDTOWN RECONFIGURED: THE GRAND CENTRAL AREA AND TUDOR CITY.'' Covers the skyscraper boom of the 1920's and 30's and the transformation of waterfront slums into Tudor City. Meets Sunday at 1 p.m. at the Philip Morris Building, at the southwest corner of Park Avenue and 42nd Street. Sponsored by the Municipal Art Society. Fee, $15; $12 for Society members. Information: (212) 935-3960.

''FROM PAGES TO PAVEMENT,'' Manhattan. Includes locations mentioned in seven novels set in the gaslight era. Meets Sunday at 2 p.m. at the arch in Washington Square. Fee: $10. Sponsored by Street Smarts N.Y. Information: (212) 969-8262.

''PROSPECT PARK, BROOKLYN: NO DESTINATION WALK'' consists of a four-to-five mile walk through the park. Meets Sunday at 11 a.m. at the token booth of the Prospect Park, Brooklyn stop on the D train. Fee, $3. Sponsored by the Outdoors Club. Information: (718) 998-3793.

''JEWISH GANGSTER TOUR,'' Lower Manhattan, will deglamorize the legends of Bugsy Siegel, Meyer Lansky, Arnold Rothstein and others. Meets Sunday at 2 p.m. inside Schapiro's Wine Cellars, 126 Rivington Street. Fee, $12. Sponsored by Dr. Phil: New York Talks and Walks. Information: (888) 377-4455.

''LITTLE ODESSA,'' Brighton Beach, Brooklyn. Covers the culture and foods of the growing community of Jews from the former Soviet Union, ending with an optional meal at a restaurant. Meets Sunday at 10:30 a.m. at the southeast corner of 43rd Street and Avenue of the Americas in Manhattan and at 11:40 a.m. in Brooklyn at the intersection of Brighton Beach and Coney Island Avenue. Fee, $5, plus $5 for food. Sponsored by Adventure on a Shoestring. Information and meeting places: (212) 265-2663.

HARLEM GOSPEL TOUR. A tour that includes stops at a church and several cultural institutions. Meets on Sundays at 10 a.m. on the southwest corner of Lenox Avenue and 116th Street. Fee: $20. Sponsored by Harlem Heritage Tours. Information: (212) 280-7888.
